repnme.cdata!:
Mauritania - Agricultural Sector Adjustment
            and Investment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Agricultural Sector Adjustment and
            Investment Project (ASAIP) in Mauritania. there were three
            major objectives: (i) to improve incentives to farmers and
            private investors; (ii) to increase the effectiveness of the
            public sector (Ministry for Rural Development (MRD) and
            SONADER, the national rural development agency) and improve
            programming and monitoring of sector investments; and (iii)
            to identify development techniques and institutional
            arrangements conducive to a less drought-vulnerable
            livestock sector and more sustainable desertification
            control. Bank's performance was satisfactory.
            Borrower's performance was satisfactory. The key
            lessons learned were as follows: (i) the government's
            capacity to implement the operation should be honestly
            evaluated and assistance to strengthen this capacity should
            be included in the project if necessary; (ii) more
            supervision resources need to be allocated than would
            normally be the case for either investment or adjustment
            operations; (iii) government's withdrawal from the
            traditional functions of management and control should be
            done gradually, and adequate support should be provided to
            help ease the transition; (iv) the hybrid character of the
            operation, where investments supported reform actions,
            proved to be effective and made the reform program more
            meaningful to those responsible for its implementation; and
            (v) under the given circumstances in Mauritania, irrigated
            rice production for the domestic market is not economically
            viable unless it is associated with other irrigated crops
            and unless this production system is integrated with the
            rest of the agricultural sector.
